text:
:woman-raising-hand::skin-tone-4: Hi there! I have a question for you:

> From your experience, what can potentially bring better results: B2B SaaS company blogs with articles *not signed by anyone* OR B2B SaaS company blogs with articles *signed by content marketers/writers (who might specialize in that niche, but aren’t trained in that field — e.g., psychology)*?
Would love to hear your thoughts! :brown_heart:

elements.text: Hi there! I have a question for you:
From your experience, what can potentially bring better results: B2B SaaS company blogs with articles
OR B2B SaaS company blogs with articles
signed by content marketers/writers (who might specialize in that niche, but aren’t trained in that field — e.g., psychology)
Would love to hear your thoughts!

text: anyone have any experience with video licensing? we’re looking to use video footage, with attribution, to help build out a brief case study clip. it comes from the client company’s youtube channel, but are we going to get sanctioned for using this footage promoting our own services?

elements.text: anyone have any experience with video licensing? we’re looking to use video footage, with attribution, to help build out a brief case study clip. it comes from the client company’s youtube channel, but are we going to get sanctioned for using this footage promoting our own services?

text:
Not a lawyer or expert here, but generally the risk is proportional to the sizes of the entities involved.

If you're a small, scrappy shop it can be easier to beg forgiveness than ask for permission. Worst* outcome is you get a cease + desist and add ice to your relationship with that client. Is that risk tenable?

You could also always ask to use it. Or ask who owns it. That could lead down a quagmire that ultimately ends in "no, you don't have my/our permission"

* (I'll emphasize again that I'm not a lawyer, so maybe it could be way worse. Though common sense tells me that it makes little sense for a company to spend a ton in legal fees to crush out someone for using a clip. Easier/cheaper to scare them with legal posturing IF you care and IF you even notice... but sometimes people are cruel)

text:
Lots of Q's lately about bylines!

My instinct is that this a classic 80/20 issue. Lots of energy spent worrying about something that doesn't move any needles.

Bylines don't shake things up, it's the power of the content. I don't have data, but my instinct says the difference is negligible. Bylines are generally a vanity metric. Unless your author is [Insert Huge Celebrity], and even then your results will come from promoting that fact elsewhere.

There are all sorts of possible exceptions and niche cases. In that case, I doubt we'll have the answer... and your best bet is run tests. Do both for a good number of pieces and run an analysis!

text: I agree with <@U01AHL8AGBB> to a degree. Unless the author has a strong personal brand and has earned some authority on a given set of topics, the byline is more likely to be negligible in most cases. That's not to say your authors can't build that credibility, they can. It just has to be a dedicated part of your strategy to do so.

elements.text: to a degree. Unless the author has a strong personal brand and has earned some authority on a given set of topics, the byline is more likely to be negligible in most cases. That's not to say your authors can't build that credibility, they can. It just has to be a dedicated part of your strategy to do so.

text: I will say that when I freelance, I am more keen to share articles I am published on because the byline validates me talking about it. It’s hard to explain but it feels weird linking articles that I worked on in my portfolio and on my LinkedIn page if I don’t have a byline to _*prove*_ I worked on it to my audience. I typically like social posts about my work regardless, but it’s less likely to wind up in my portfolio or prominently displayed on my LinkedIn if I don’t have a byline.

I worked on it to my audience. I typically like social posts about my work regardless, but it’s less likely to wind up in my portfolio or prominently displayed on my LinkedIn if I don’t have a byline.

text: I agree with Jordy generally, but I also think it depends on the metric for success. If the measure is traffic overall, then I think Jordy's point is right. If the goal with the blog articles is to bring legitimacy/authority to your brand, then having an authored post from a CEO or a SME that is a visionary topic is beneficial (vs company authored) because it might serve as a pedestal for a bigger platform (conference, op-ed in media outlet, etc.) to promote his/her/they perspective.

text: I'm with you on this, <@U01S6GPFXM1>. I'm not necessarily thinking about traffic, but about leads. And I wonder if seeing that someone's content wasn't written by a practitioner in a given field (but instead by a writer who does specialize in that niche) could deter a potential lead from booking that demo or downloading that eBook.
